item.dc:creator: rarodriguez

item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: group1
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my website. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: SubCategoryTemplate
item.dc:creator: kweaverghs
item.content:encoded:
Description of subcategory here. Each paragraph needs to be contained within the appropriate div tag and class for all paragraphs to be formatted properly. Wordpress removes them otherwise. On the final paragraph add a break tag before the closing div for the space between the paragraph and the button. Doing this outside the closing div tag creates too much whitespace between the two.
Return Home

Click Below for More Information


-Accordion will be added here once installed-

Example Formatting - The Following Can Be Deleted Upon Use

 
With the development of the Las Vegas Strip in the 1940s and 1950s into an entertainment destination and the growth of the casino areas in Reno, Elko, and Hawthorne in the 1950s, floorshows became a means to attract tourists to Nevada's hotels and casinos. Many hotel-casinos employed black entertainers to perform at these floorshows, but famous black celebrities were not immune from the effects of segregation in Nevada. In Las Vegas and Reno, black performers such as Sammy Davis Jr., Louis Armstrong, Lena Horne, Nat King Cole, and others could not stay in or eat at the venues in which they performed. Stars such as Louis Armstrong were forced to use the rear entrances of many of these buildings.
Since these entertainers could not stay in the hotel-casinos, they were forced to stay at private homes in Reno or at all-black establishments or homes on the Westside, which developed as the primary black residential and business community in Las Vegas during the 1930s and 1940s. This situation earned Nevada the epithet “The Mississippi of the West” from black entertainers. Josephine Baker, a celebrated star of stage and screen, challenged segregationist practices in Las Vegas by using her status to allow local blacks to attend her show at the El Rancho.
Segregation did not only affect black entertainers but also those who worked at hotel-casinos at the time. Their experiences offer a different perspective on how black entertainers were treated. Morton Saiger worked at the Last Frontier in Las Vegas throughout this era and was responsible for the transportation of entertainers back and forth between the Westside and the club. In Reno, Yvonne Davis worked at Harolds Club in the 1950s and 1960s and saw firsthand how segregation affected black entertainers in that community.
Return Home

Click on the Images Below for More Information


[gallery ids="165,19,16,163,94,17,18,24,14,23" order="DESC" orderby="ID"]

item.title: Mining In Nevada
item.dc:creator: patriciaeusta
item.content:encoded:
[gallery ids="1274,1281,1279,892"]
 
For almost 150 years, mining has played an important role in Nevada's economy and in the lifestyles of its residents.
Many of the towns throughout the state were founded around mines and mills, and the industry continues to impact Nevada to the present day, whether through investment and employment booms and busts or environmental and safety statutes. From individually owned claims to corporate enterprises, from the self-taught tramp miner to the engineering graduates from the Mackay School of Mines at the University of Nevada, Reno, the characters and businesses involved in the state have influenced how residents see themselves and how they are perceived by those outside of Nevada. The four components in this module explore mining from a number of topical perspectives.
 
Click on any image above to learn more about Mining in Nevada.
[accordion openfirst="true"] [accordion-item title="▼ Mining Economics"] Mining in Nevada has changed greatly over the last 150 years, due primarily to advances in technology and in prospecting techniques. During the nineteenth century mining boom on the Comstock, large veins of ore—mainly gold and silver—were being mined. While company mines were perhaps more highly visible, small, individually owned mines were also common in Nevada, and it was not unusual for a family to own a small claim and mine it themselves. Read more [/accordion-item] [accordion-item title="▼ Effect of WWII on Mining"] World War II had a great influence on mining in Nevada. While restrictions on gold mining had begun almost immediately after Pearl Harbor, the War Production Board issued Limitation Order L-208 in October of 1942, effectively closing the nation’s gold mines all together. The government’s intent in shutting down gold mines was to focus mining on strategic metals and minerals such as lead, zinc, copper and tungsten, which were needed for the war effort. Gold and other precious metals such as silver were deemed “non-strategic.” While many individual miners managed to find employment in strategic-metal mines, the closing of gold and silver operations had a significant impact on the communities that relied on them for jobs as well as support of local businesses. Read more [/accordion-item] [accordion-item title="▼ Life in Mining Communities"] Many towns in Nevada exist today because of mining. When a large mine was opened, towns were built around them to provide for the men who were working in the mines and their families. It was recognized that in order to keep good miners, companies needed to have comfortable living conditions, so it was not uncommon for companies to not only build bunkhouses and provide room and board, but to build entire towns for their workers. Read more [/accordion-item] [accordion-item title="▼ Mining Regulations"] While regulations of mines on a state level began in Nevada in 1909, restrictions and legal requirements began to intensify with the rising popularity of the environmental movement in the 1970s and escalated even further during the Clinton administration in the 1990s. Both the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) enacted measures to protect workers and the environment, and many of these were at odds with the mining industry's practices. The lengthy permitting process and on-site inspections attempt to control the effect mining has on the surrounding environment, especially the groundwater, run off, air, and soil. Today, the permitting process to operate a mine may take years to complete. Some feel the regulations are too intrusive, while others feel they are much needed. Read more [/accordion-item] [/accordion]

item.title: The Civil Rights Movement In Nevada
item.dc:creator: patriciaeusta
item.content:encoded:
[gallery ids="1250,1251,2051,1289,1253,1249"]
 
During the Civil Rights Movement of the 1950s and 1960s, the situation in Nevada reflected, to a certain extent, what was going on in the rest of the country. Referred to by some as the "Mississippi of the West," the state experienced its own growing pains during that era, with boycotts (actual or threatened), protests, the forming of organizations, and lawsuits. While there were civil rights proponents in other parts of Nevada, much of this activity took place in the southern part of the state, where a strong NAACP chapter and equally strong leaders worked to desegregate many aspects of life, from housing and employment to education. They were assisted in large part by Governor Grant Sawyer, who used his power and influence to push the cause of civil rights at the state level between 1959 and 1965.

Click on any image above to learn more about the Civil Rights Movement in Nevada.

[accordion openfirst="true"] [accordion-item title="▼ Black Entertainers"] With the development of the Las Vegas Strip in the 1940s and 1950s into an entertainment destination and the growth of the casino areas in Reno, Elko, and Hawthorne in the 1950s, floorshows became a means to attract tourists to Nevada's hotels and casinos. Many hotel-casinos employed black entertainers to perform at these floorshows, but famous black celebrities were not immune from the effects of segregation in Nevada. In Las Vegas and Reno, black performers such as Sammy Davis Jr., Louis Armstrong, Lena Horne, Nat King Cole, and others could not stay in or eat at the venues in which they performed. Stars such as Louis Armstrong were forced to use the rear entrances of many of these buildings. Read more [/accordion-item] [accordion-item title="▼ Housing & Employment"] With the construction of Boulder Dam outside of Las Vegas, segregation in employment and housing became a focal point for the civil rights movement in Nevada. During the 1930s, the dam project was the major source of employment for the area. At first blacks were denied employment due to race, and it was only through the intervention of the Las Vegas NAACP branch that they were allowed to work at Boulder Dam. Even then, blacks were systematically excluded from certain types of jobs and housing, and it was during this time that the Westside began to develop as the primary black residential and business community in Las Vegas. Read more [/accordion-item] [accordion-item title="▼ Legislation"] Legislation in Nevada to end racial discrimination and give blacks civil rights did not begin until the 1950s. The first effort came in 1953, when George Rudiak presented a bill to the assembly to open public accommodations to blacks. The bill failed, and no other legislative attempts occurred until Grant Sawyer’s election as the Governor of Nevada in 1958. Read more [/accordion-item] [accordion-item title="▼ Moulin Rouge Agreement"] By the end of the 1940s, the gaming industry was the major source of employment in Las Vegas, but segregation limited blacks to the most menial jobs on the Strip and denied them access to the hotel-casinos as customers. The black community in the 1950s sought an end to racial discrimination using boycotts and demonstrations, which culminated in 1960 with the Moulin Rouge Agreement. Read more [/accordion-item] [accordion-item title="▼ Organizations"] The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, or the NAACP, emerged as the leading organization in the struggle for civil rights and the end of segregation in Nevada. The Las Vegas chapter was formed in 1928 through the efforts of Arthur McCants, Clarence Ray, Bill Jones, a Mrs. Nettles, and Zimmy Turner, with McCants serving as the first NAACP president in Nevada. Read more [/accordion-item] [accordion-item title="▼ Segregated Education"] In the 1930s and 1940s, the schools in Las Vegas were segregated at the elementary and junior high school levels, with the lone high school being integrated. The Westside neighborhood, which developed into the primary black residential and business community in Las Vegas during the 1930s and 1940s, had only one school, and that school was in substandard condition. Read more [/accordion-item] [/accordion]

item.title: Nevada During World War II
item.dc:creator: patriciaeusta
item.content:encoded:
[gallery ids="1235,1234,1236"]
  The main facts of World War II are reasonably well known to most adults. Between 1941 and 1945, the United States and other Allied powers did battle against the Axis countries with staggering losses of life and levels of destruction on a global level, but what effect did the war have on a more local scale? How did this conflagration impact various groups of Nevadans? With the United States at war against Japan, Italy, and Germany, there was the serious question of what happened to immigrants from these countries and their descendants who had settled in Nevada. Some Japanese Americans living in the state were interned, as were others across the nation, but not all were forced to leave their homes and businesses. As for German Americans and Italian Americans, their treatment was also inconsistent but was generally less severe and seemed to have at least something to do with where exactly they were living at the time and how strong and deeply rooted their individual communities were. And while some immigrant groups experienced difficulties during the war, it opened up opportunities for many women, who found themselves able to serve in jobs and positions that were not available to them prior to World War II. The components in this module address the experiences of the above groups of people in Nevada during the war years.
 

Click on any image above to learn more about Nevada During World War II.

[accordion openfirst="true"] [accordion-item title="▼ Italian & German Americans"] During World War II, German Americans and Italian Americans were in a difficult position, as they were associated (either directly or through their heritage) with two of the nations at war with the United States. For the most part, there were few restrictions on German Americans, perhaps because they had been a presence in northern Nevada for so long. Any limitations on the activities of Italian Americans seem to have been sporadic and inconsistent. Some chroniclers recall no regulations, while others remember the internment of non-citizen family members or having firearms or shortwave radios confiscated from their homes. Neither group experienced the widespread uprooting and relocations that Japanese Americans were subjected to.
Read more [/accordion-item] [accordion-item title="▼ Japanese Americans in Nevada"] During World War II, the experiences of Japanese-Americans in Nevada were different from their Italian-American or German-American counterparts, and the government singled them out for more severe restrictions. Not all Japanese Americans in Nevada were sent to internment camps, but those that were had to give up their homes, possessions, and businesses because the government feared that they would support Japan during the war.
Read more [/accordion-item] [accordion-item title="▼ Women During the War"] During World War II, women entered military service in unprecedented numbers, serving as auxiliary forces for the army and navy, thus freeing up men for combat. Women's experiences differed widely depending upon the group with which they were affiliated.
Read more [/accordion-item] [/accordion]

item.dc:creator: kweaverghs
item.content:encoded:
-Img code here if applicable-
Description given about person/event here. Strong tag used for the name of the person/event. Format can easily be transferred into an accordion later if needed.
 

Transcript

transcript goes here

Previous Entry Return Home Next Entry
The following example can be deleted.

[caption id="attachment_94" align="alignleft" width="300"] Clarence Ray, 1991[/caption]
Clarence Ray (1900-1993) began his career as a professional gambler in California and in 1925 moved to Las Vegas to continue his work until his retirement from the Dunes in 1983. He helped found the Nevada NAACP in 1928 and later the Nevada Voters League. Ray was interviewed by Helen Blue and Jamie Coughtry in 1989 and 1991.
 
  [audio mp3="http://digitalhistory.acs.unr.edu/hist300a/sp2017/group1/wp-content/uploads/sites/19/2017/10/JohnsonL7BE-Edited.mp3"][/audio]

Transcript

During this time, blacks didn't go downtown, and quite a number of whites didn't come over here to the Westside. I've heard people call Las Vegas the "Mississippi of the West." I think that came from the black entertainers, because people in the big hotels would hire all the black entertainers they could get, but they wouldn't let them stay at those hotels. That started them coming over to the Westside to stay. Mrs. Shaw took care of a lot of people who stayed here, and then there was a lady by the name of Simpson, who built a big house that had eight or ten rooms that she rented.

Additional Images

This page

[accordion] [accordion-item title="Click here to view an external link example."] Additional WWII oral histories can be found at the University of Nevada Oral History Archive website. Select the link below for more Nevada WWII related oral histories. The website opens in a separate tab.

Nevada WW II Veteran's project

[/accordion-item] [accordion-item title="Click Here for Instructions on Adding an External Reference"]
  1. Open the page that is to contain the external link.
  2. Position the cursor where you want to place the external link.
  3. Add text that describes the external website content.
  4. Select the Link icon from the page editor tool bar.
  5. Enter the URL for the external webpage then click the link cog.
  6. In the Insert/edit link form, enter link text. It is advised also to select "Open link in a new tab."
  7. Click Update.
[/accordion-item] [/accordion]

item.title: Black Entertainers
item.dc:creator: kweaverghs
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_2152" align="alignleft" width="300"] Nat King Cole, Harry Belafonte[/caption]

With the development of the Las Vegas Strip in the 1940s and 1950s into an entertainment destination and the growth of the casino areas in Reno, Elko, and Hawthorne in the 1950s, floorshows became a means to attract tourists to Nevada's hotels and casinos. Many hotel-casinos employed black entertainers to perform at these floorshows, but famous black celebrities were not immune from the effects of segregation in Nevada. In Las Vegas and Reno, black performers such as Sammy Davis Jr., Louis Armstrong, Lena Horne, Nat King Cole, and others could not stay in or eat at the venues in which they performed. Stars such as Louis Armstrong were forced to use the rear entrances of many of these buildings.
Since these entertainers could not stay in the hotel-casinos, they were forced to stay at private homes in Reno or at all-black establishments or homes on the Westside, which developed as the primary black residential and business community in Las Vegas during the 1930s and 1940s. This situation earned Nevada the epithet “The Mississippi of the West” from black entertainers. Josephine Baker, a celebrated star of stage and screen, challenged segregationist practices in Las Vegas by using her status to allow local blacks to attend her show at the El Rancho.
Segregation did not only affect black entertainers but also those who worked at hotel-casinos at the time. Their experiences offer a different perspective on how black entertainers were treated. Morton Saiger worked at the Last Frontier in Las Vegas throughout this era and was responsible for the transportation of entertainers back and forth between the Westside and the club. In Reno, Yvonne Davis worked at Harolds Club in the 1950s and 1960s and saw firsthand how segregation affected black entertainers in that community.
Return Home

item.title: Fred Settlemeyer
item.dc:creator: rarodriguez
item.content:encoded:
Fred Settlemeyer (1892-1989) was a rancher of German descent living in the Carson Valley during World War II. Settlemeyer was interviewed by Mary Ellen Glass in 1970.
 




Transcript

World War II came along, and again, there was some talk of there being disloyalty in the community. But again, I must emphasize that it was largely talk around the bars, with possibly a bit of noise, and I think perhaps the same arguments that people would have about politics, which might be a bit heated. But as far as definite disloyalty, it existed, if at all, to such a small extent that I feel that at all times ignoring it would have been much the best policy.
 
Previous Home Next

item.title: Grace Dangberg 🔊
item.dc:creator: rarodriguez
item.content:encoded:
Grace Dangberg (1896-1985) was raised in a German-American family in the Carson Valley. She later became a well-known anthropologist specializing in the Great Basin area. Dangberg was interviewed by R.T. King in 1984.
           
[audio mp3="http://digitalhistory.acs.unr.edu/hist300a/sp2017/group1/wp-content/uploads/sites/19/2017/10/DangbergG.mp3"][/audio]

Transcript

During World War II we had a German gardener who was—he for years distributed the vegetables from our garden hither and yon for a bottle of liquor. So he got very high on liquor one day in the town of Gardnerville, and he stood out in front of the French Hotel—or one of the hotels, one of the Basque hotels, anyway, French-Basque—and heiled Hitler. [laughter] The first thing we knew, why, we had the FBI in here, and they wanted to interview us because we were the employer. And I never will forget: my uncle—who was a very charming man, among other things true of him—brought Klaus in following—no, he brought the FBI men into the office and went into his private office and told him that it was just a joke, because old Klaus was perfectly incapable of doing anything that related to the war or anything else. But he was just high, in his quite usual way, and this is what created the incident.

***End of Audio***

 
Previous Home Next

item.title: Delia Rossi 🔊
item.dc:creator: rarodriguez
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_21" align="alignleft" width="250"] Oral History Italian Northern Nevadan Project[/caption]
Delia Rossi (1917-) was a young Italian-American woman living in Reno during World War II. She and her family would go to visit the former Italian POWs who were working with the Quartermasters Corps at the Sierra Army Depot in Herlong, California, about sixty miles north of Reno. Rossi was interviewed by Mary Larson in 2005.
 
[audio mp3="http://digitalhistory.acs.unr.edu/hist300a/sp2017/group1/wp-content/uploads/sites/19/2017/10/RossiD_new-edit.mp3"][/audio]

Download audio file

Transcript

[Italian POWs who had become part of the U.S. Quartermaster’s Service were at the ammunition depot in Herlong, California.] One of the things we wanted to talk about was the camp up at Herlong. You said you’d gone up there a couple of times with some of your girlfriends. Do you want to—? Yes. Well, Lena [Porta Green] was there, too, with her mother, but we only went there two times. My dad was interested to see if he did have a nephew there by the name of Rossi, you know. Ah. So you’d heard that there might be a relative there, so you went up there to check? Right. And did folks from the area, from Reno go up pretty frequently? Yeah, there was people that went up there. When they heard there was Italian kids there, they were all curious to go up there. Right. So when you went up there, what would you do? They had music for dancing, and then we would eat there. And oh, they would make the most delicious cakes, and the cooks they had there were something outstanding, really. They had good food. So it wasn’t the Italians that were doing the cooking, but the cooks at the camp? Right. We’d have lunch, because you know, it’s quite a long ways to drive. I mean we’d visit, and then we’d come home. See, we’d leave early, because we never wanted to come home in the dark. Do you remember seeing any of the barracks or anything like that, what those were like or what the area were like? Well, all we saw, they showed us one and there was a lot of cots, you know. Are there any particular soldiers that you remember? There’s pictures of him and this other fellow, but other than that, we didn’t, you know, fraternize with too many of them. Do you remember their names and where they were from? Well, this one here, that you saw the picture over there on this poster,  he was from Rome and he could speak English fluently and write it, you know. And he was the pilot?  Yes. And I think you said he was a lieutenant, was he? Yes. And did they come here straight from—do you know where they were captured? I don’t have the least idea, but they told us that when they hit the United States, they took them down to some southern state. And they said that they loaded them on freight cars with pitchforks. If it was true or not, I don’t know. And they had very poor food down there, but when they came here, they felt like they were in paradise, you know, because they treated them good, and they had good food—good cooks. Were there a lot of romances between the local girls and the prisoners of war? [laughter] Well, this guy wanted to marry me, and he wrote all these beautiful love letters, and then finally he wrote me a “Dear Jane,” because he said, “I found a girl,” which I was happy that he did. [laughter]
***End of Audio***
 
Previous Home Next

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Delia Rossi (1917-) was a young Italian-American woman living in Reno during World War II. She and her family would go to visit the former Italian POWs...

item.title: Elmer Vacchina 🔊
item.dc:creator: rarodriguez
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_23" align="alignleft" width="294"] Oral History Italian Northern Nevadan Project[/caption]
Elmer Vacchina (1920-2015) belonged to one of Reno's Italian-American families and served in the army during World War II. Vacchina was interviewed by Mary Larson in 2005.
 
[audio mp3="http://digitalhistory.acs.unr.edu/hist300a/sp2017/group1/wp-content/uploads/sites/19/2017/10/VacchinaE.mp3"][/audio]

Transcript

One thing that we haven’t had a chance to discuss was the camp out in Herlong. [Former Italian POWs who became part of the U.S. Quartermasters unit were housed out there.] You said you had heard your father talk about that.

Well obviously I was gone all the time; I was in the service. But I remember my father saying that they would occasionally bring food and go up and visit. It wasn’t too popular with a lot of the citizens of the city, but a lot of the Italians still did it, and he did it occasionally. And they would go up and bring them prosciutto or salamis and various other things that they weren’t getting at army rations, and they would go up and visit them occasionally.

***End of Audio***

Do you know what their situation was up there, if they were still POW’s? They were all POW’s. That’s what they were. They were all prisoners of war. They’d been shipped over here just to get them out of the way.
 
Previous Home Next

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Elmer Vacchina (1920-2015) belonged to one of Reno’s Italian-American families and served in the army during World War II. Vacchina was interviewed by...

item.title: Italo Gavazzi 🔊
item.dc:creator: rarodriguez
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_18" align="alignleft" width="259"] Oral History Italian Northern Nevadan Project[/caption]
Italo Gavazzi (1922-) was a student at the University of Nevada at the time of the war and grew up in an Italian-American family living on the Comstock. Gavazzi was interviewed by Kara Geiger in 2004.
 
[audio mp3="http://digitalhistory.acs.unr.edu/hist300a/sp2017/group1/wp-content/uploads/sites/19/2017/10/GavazziP.mp3"][/audio]

Transcript

Now during World War II, I understand that some Italian Americans were faced with certain restrictions. Can you tell me something about that?

Yes, there were a few restrictions. My mother, not being a citizen, she had to register every so often. And she would go up to the post office and register with Tex Gladding, of course, who had known her all his life. [laughter] But it was something that had to be done. And also, we were not allowed to have a shortwave radio. That had to be removed from the radio that we had. And that was about it, as I recall.

***End of Audio***

Then, of course, there were some bad feelings toward Italians at that time. You know, when you’re in the war and you’re on the enemy’s side, people give you dirty looks. But, of course, a good many of the Italian boys that were in Virginia City were fighting in World War II. They were drafted and were in the service so that moderated out.
 
Previous Home Next

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Italo Gavazzi (1922-) was a student at the University of Nevada at the time of the war and grew up in an Italian-American family living on the Comstock...

item.title: Teresa Manfredi 🔊
item.dc:creator: rarodriguez
item.content:encoded:
Teresa Manfredi (1923-), the daughter of Italian immigrants, worked at the First National Bank in Reno during the 1940s. Manfredi was interviewed by Mary Larson in 2005.
             
[audio mp3="http://digitalhistory.acs.unr.edu/hist300a/sp2017/group1/wp-content/uploads/sites/19/2017/10/ManfrediT.mp3"][/audio]

Transcript

Now, during World War II were there any restrictions on Italians or Italian Americans that you remember?

I don’t know of anybody here in Reno, but I know that my sister’s father-in-law, who was a Sicilian and lived in Sacramento—and he was the most wonderful old gentleman—had three sons in the service, and they sent him to internment.

Really, where?

I believe that they sent him to Texas. And there were enough people in Sacramento that had enough pull, or whatever it was, and they really got on them, saying, “Hey, now look. Maybe he hasn’t got a citizenship paper, but he has three sons in the service. This is not right!”

***End of Audio***
 
Previous Home Next

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Teresa Manfredi (1923-), the daughter of Italian immigrants, worked at the First National Bank in Reno during the 1940s. Manfredi was interviewed by Mary...

item.title: Nello Gonfiantini 🔊
item.dc:creator: rarodriguez
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_19" align="alignleft" width="294"] Oral History Italian Northern Nevadan Project[/caption]
Nello Gonfiantini (1926-), a native Nevadan of Italian-American descent, served in the Army Air Corps near the end of World War II. Gonfiantini was interviewed by Mary Larson in 2005.
 
[audio mp3="http://digitalhistory.acs.unr.edu/hist300a/sp2017/group1/wp-content/uploads/sites/19/2017/10/GonfiantiniN1.mp3"][/audio]

Transcript

Do you remember anything specifically about World War II, whether there were any restrictions on the Italian-American people?

Yes, I do. I remember that I had an aunt that was not an American citizen. She’d lived here many, many years, and she had restrictions. In fact, as I remember, they also—by that time their kids were in their teenage years, and they would go hunting. I think they confiscated all their guns, and my aunt couldn’t go into Gerlach, because there was a railroad there—there was a railroad track. So I don’t know if they thought she was going to sabotage the railroad, but she was not allowed to cross the railroad track. And so there was a certain amount of discrimination against Italians, that they were observed and I guess they couldn’t have firearms and they couldn’t do a few other things.

***End of Audio***

So this was for the folks who hadn’t become citizens. Yes. But we never felt any of that. Do you know if the restrictions that your aunt mentioned were legal restrictions, or if they were just informally generated within the community? No, they were legal ones….
 
Previous Home Next

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Nello Gonfiantini (1926-), a native Nevadan of Italian-American descent, served in the Army Air Corps near the end of World War II. Gonfiantini was...

item.title: Lena Porta Green 🔊
item.dc:creator: rarodriguez
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_12" align="alignleft" width="284"] Oral History Italian Northern Nevadan Project[/caption]
Lena Porta Green (1924-) was part of an Italian-American family that visited the former Italian POWs at the Sierra Army Depot in Herlong, California, about sixty miles north of Reno. Porta Green was interviewed by Mary Larson in 2005.
 
[audio mp3="http://digitalhistory.acs.unr.edu/hist300a/sp2017/group1/wp-content/uploads/sites/19/2017/10/GreenL.mp3"][/audio]

Transcript

Do you remember, were there any restrictions on the Italian-American community at the time that you remember? No. Nothing like that? No, not like the poor Japanese went through. And, of course, some of the Germans were ostracized, I know that. But the Italians I don’t think ever [were], because I think we’ve always had that feeling for America that, you know, just [it is the] land of opportunity, and it was for most of us. So, no, I don’t remember any slurs or anything else.  
***End of Audio***

item.title: Piero Zorio 🔊
item.dc:creator: rarodriguez
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_24" align="alignleft" width="282"] Oral History Italian Northern Nevadan Project[/caption]
Piero Zorio (1933-2010) came from an Italian-American family, and he was a teenager in Winnemucca during World War II. Zorio was interviewed by Kara Geiger in 2005.
 
[audio mp3="http://digitalhistory.acs.unr.edu/hist300a/sp2017/group1/wp-content/uploads/sites/19/2017/10/ZorioP.mp3"][/audio]

Transcript

One thing that I want to record that was really funny to me, during the war—World War II—during World War II, one day—and I don’t know what year it was—it was really hilarious. A sheriff’s deputy knocked on our door, and I says, “What’s up?”

And he said, “You’re an Italian family?” I said, “Yes.” He says, “You got any guns and shortwave radios?” And I said, “You got to be kidding!” I think I was in grade school. I don’t know, seventh or eighth grade. I said, “You got to be kidding!” He said, “No.” He said, “I have orders to take weapons from Italians.” As you know, Italy was allied with Hitler during World War II. And I thought, “Yes, sure, I can give you something.” I had an old radio, but I didn’t even know if it had a shortwave band on it. I had taken that thing apart a million times. You know how kids take apart and put them back together? I said, “Here, you can have this.” And then there was an old shotgun in the basement of my house, and it was all rusted out, I’m not kidding you. I don’t think it was ever fired for, I don’t know, fifty years. The stock was broken on it. So I went down, and I gave him that. I said, “Here, you can have this.” And he said, “Oh, OK.” He wrote it down and left. Now, I thought that was kind of an interesting thing.
***End of Audio***
 
Previous Home Next

item.title: Harold "Treat" Cafferata 🔊
item.dc:creator: rarodriguez
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_13" align="alignleft" width="300"] Reno Italian American Project; Treet Cafferata[/caption]
Harold "Treat" Cafferata (1937-) was a young boy in Reno in the early 1940s with both German- and Italian-American grandparents on his father's side. Cafferata was interviewed by Felvia Belaustegui in 2005.
 
[audio mp3="http://digitalhistory.acs.unr.edu/hist300a/sp2017/group1/wp-content/uploads/sites/19/2017/10/CafferataH-edited.mp3"][/audio]

Transcript

We were very non-Italian. But, of course, with the war years, Italy wasn’t very popular, and the Germans weren’t very popular. We certainly didn’t make much out of our ethnicity. We didn’t belong to any of the Italian functionary groups like Patty and I have joined.

***End of Audio***

item.title: Mary Forson 🔊
item.dc:creator: rarodriguez
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_17" align="alignleft" width="286"] Oral History Italian Northern Nevadan Project[/caption]
Mary Forson (1921-) worked as a clerk at the Sierra Army Depot in Herlong, California, from 1942-1945. She was one of the first employees to be hired at the facility and was there when it began operations. Forson was interviewed by Mary Larson in 2005.







 

Transcript

Since you were working at Herlong, do you remember when the Italians came to the base? Yes, they must have come in in October or November of 1942, because they asked us to go down and help at the PX when they came in, so they could get their supplies—shaving cream and things like that. But most all of the Italians were so interested in seeing some American women, and they showed us pictures of their families and their children and were trying to correspond with us. But they seemed like a very happy group.
[audio mp3="http://digitalhistory.acs.unr.edu/hist300a/sp2017/group1/wp-content/uploads/sites/19/2017/10/ForsonM-edited.mp3"][/audio]

Transcript

Most of the Italians that came into Herlong were from the North African campaign. And when our troops landed in Anzio, they captured a lot of them, and they were—most of those Italians were from the northern part of Italy, and they were blond, redheaded, and very handsome, talented.  Most all of the Italians, they were so interested in seeing some American women. They showed us pictures of their families and their children, and seemed like a very happy group.

***End of Audio***

Now, do you remember how many men there were, either with the Italian POWs that came in or with any of the ordnance companies? I don’t remember the Italians, how many they were. It had to be a hundred or so, because they had their own barracks. They were behind a fence, but they worked in the ammunition. Now, the ordnance companies that came in were for an ordnance company. Now, you mentioned that the Italian troops were housed separately. They had their own barracks, and it was behind a fence. Did that change over time after Italy allied with the United States? Not that I know of. I can’t remember. So their set-up stayed pretty much the same? Yes. What sorts of work did each group do? The ordnance companies would have been, as you said before, storing and transporting a lot of the ammunition. What did they have the Italian troops doing? They were helping. At one time, I know we had an emergency thing to get the ammunition out. We had to have it out by a certain day, so there was a whole bunch of us from the administration that went out and helped haul ammunition and put it into the railroad cars. [laughter] You had mentioned before that they had set up the mess halls. Did the Italian troops eat separately from the other troops? Yes, they ate separately. They had their own mess hall and their own interpreters and their own cooks. Do you remember anything about what they were usually served? Was it mostly Italian-type food, or was it the same sort of food? I don’t remember. I know that a lot of times when the officers had their parties and stuff, the Italians had a band. They would entertain, and they cooked sometimes, too. There was one that was quite a nice artist that painted pictures all over. I know he painted a picture for the commanding officer that was quite pretty. It was of the mountain out there, and I’ve forgotten the name of that mountain, but it’s got a road going around it. With the other units you mentioned that you had, like the 141st Ordnance Company, did you say that those were mainly black officers? No, they were black and white officers. Were those companies racially segregated at that point in time? Oh, yes. Yes, they didn’t get along with the Italians. They had their own troop area. But with the 141st, for example, was it entirely black troops? Yes. And there were no white ordnance companies there. So you mentioned that they didn’t necessarily get along with the Italian troops. Do you have any stories that you remember about that? No, just the things I’ve heard, you know, because they’d get into stabbings and that kind of thing loading ammunition and stuff. Did one group think the other group was getting better treatment? I don’t know what their cause was. Just that there was conflict. But generally they were in different areas, except for when they were working? Yes, when they were working. Now, you said that the Italian soldiers had a separate area, and it was fenced. What kind of privileges did they have as far as being able to leave the camp? Was it pretty much the same as the other soldiers? I think so. They had to get their permission and could go and be back, but they kept pretty good track of them. But they were allowed to do what they wanted, if they signed in and out. What can you recall about their treatment in the local communities like Doyle? I don’t know, because we only got into Reno on the weekend, and we never saw any of them. You mentioned that they had a band. What kind of things would they do socially? I don’t know what the Italians would do, but I know they entertained for the officers’ club and tended bar and had their picnics and stuff that they did. Now, with the folks that would have been working over in the officers’ club, were those mainly Italian officers, do you think? No, I don’t think so. Did you have a number of Italian officers there? I think there were, yes, but I never ran into any of them, but I’m sure they must have. They had to have been there. They had their regular officers, but then they had their NCO’s like this that ran everything. So do you remember having groups come up from Reno or down from Susanville to visit any of the Italians? No. And you said that it would be the officers’ club that had different festivities. Were those things where people from Susanville or Reno would come, or was it just strictly officers? No, they’re just strictly an officers’ club. With the band they had, what kind of music would they play? Oh, old-fashioned music, you know. [laughter] What was popular at the time. Now, within that group of soldiers that were there, are there any particular soldiers that you remember that you can tell me about? Well, I remember one, Mario, and I can’t remember his last name. It was like Compagnoni or Compantelli or something, and he was, I think, from Palermo. He would always send me little notes. On our way from our housing project we had to walk by the prisoners, and they’re behind the fence, and he’d always be standing there waiting for me and would pass me notes then, send notes into the adjutant’s office for me, and that was as far as it got. We had a correspondence thing. He was a nice man. He was short like myself, so . . . . [laughter] Did he write the letters himself, or did somebody help him? I don’t think so. No, he couldn’t speak English or write. Now, I’ve heard that there were a lot of romances between some of the gentlemen and local women. There could have been. I knew of none. Do you know of any Italians from the camp who ended up staying around? Not that I know of, but they were still there when I left in August of 1945. It was the same group of Italians the whole time. And they were still pretty much doing the same types of work? Yes. Because Germany had surrendered, and now they were shipping everything to Japan or out in the Pacific.
 
Previous Home Next

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Mary Forson (1921-) worked as a clerk at the Sierra Army Depot in Herlong, California, from 1942-1945. She was one of the first employees to be hired...

item.title: Robert Capurro 🔊
item.dc:creator: rarodriguez
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_14" align="alignleft" width="300"] Oral History Italian Northern Nevadan Project[/caption]
Robert Capurro (1941-) was born in Reno into an Italian-American family and was a young boy during World War II. Capurro was interviewed by Kara Geiger in 2005.
 
[audio mp3="http://digitalhistory.acs.unr.edu/hist300a/sp2017/group1/wp-content/uploads/sites/19/2017/10/CapurroR-edited.mp3"][/audio]

Transcript

In Reno I don’t think the restrictions on Italian-Americans during the war were very stringent. Now, back East—the cities along the ocean—there were restrictions, because we were against the United States, so, you know, we were the bad guys, part of the Axis.

Now, there was a doctor in Reno here that took care of all the Italian families. His name was Dr. Miniggio. He was a very prominent doctor. As I said earlier, if you were sick, he came to you; you didn’t go to him. He did all his house calls on foot; he never owned an automobile. He took care of all the Italians. He studied in Germany. He was a very good doctor. And he was kind of sympathetic to the German cause, so he was picked up and arrested in Reno here, thinking that he might be a spy or something. And it was my father that got him out of jail, and to his dying day, our family was it; I mean, he took care of us.

***End of Audio***

To my knowledge, that’s the only thing that I heard of, of any restrictions during the war being placed on anybody. We were non-strategic here. I mean, there was nothing we could do to either help or hinder the war effort, and we lived our own lives, so there were no restrictions that I know of. There was a prisoner-of-war camp in Herlong, California, which is north of here, that housed some German prisoners, but mainly Italian prisoners, and I can remember my aunts' talking that they would go visit them on the weekends. I guess they, again, were not felt a threat. They would even let the prisoners out to come to Reno to have dinner on Sundays as long as they were back on Monday. So that was a prisoner-of-war camp in Herlong. So you said you had relatives who would go visit them? Yes, my aunts and their friends. You know, during the war they were right in their twenties, and they were all single, so they used to get a big kick. I can still ask my aunt today, and she’ll tell you the same thing—she’s still alive—about the Italian prisoners in Herlong. So they weren’t considered a threat, and they were just people.
 
Previous Home Next

item.title: Noah Smernoff 🔊
item.dc:creator: rarodriguez
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_346" align="alignleft" width="281"] Dr. Noah Smernoff[/caption]
Dr. Noah Smernoff (1904-2006) was the company doctor at the Nevada Consolidated Copper Company in the Ely area at the time of the war and witnessed the internment of the community's Japanese- American families. Dr. Noah Smernoff was interviewed by R.T. King in 1989 to 1990.
 
[audio mp3="http://digitalhistory.acs.unr.edu/hist300a/sp2017/group1/wp-content/uploads/sites/19/2017/10/SmernoffN.mp3"][/audio]

Transcript

During the war, when the Japanese were interned all over the country, our Japanese [at Nevada Consolidated Copper Company, later Kennecott Copper, in the Ely District] were also interned. And I felt real sorry for them, because many of them were good American families and the children were American-born and they didn't deserve that kind of treatment. I thought that that was very unfair.

About how many were there?

There were probably twenty families.

Oh, that’s a lot of people!

That was a lot of people and their children. I felt that they really were treated quite shabbily.

Were they sent to the Manzanar camp, the one down in California?

Down in California, yes.

Can you recall any of the details of their departure?

I think their departure was a very sad thing for the whole community.

***End of Audio***

The Japanese children had been integrated into the schools, and they participated in athletics and everything. The community felt that it was a very unfair thing to do to them because they had been good citizens, and there was no sentiment for removing them that I ever heard. The management of the company was not for it, and I don't think the people were, either. Nobody held any enmity toward the Japanese families there. As to the actual removal, I can only recall that some federal people showed up, and the Japanese were just transported out in buses. I am not sure, but I think that they left their possessions there to be taken care of later. I think the company took care of shipping a lot of their stuff down to California for them. After the war, the Japanese families apparently did not return to the Ely district, for we didn't see any more of them there. There had been a few Orientals in Ely running a couple of little restaurants, and they were moved out, too. Some of them did come back to the restaurants, but none came back to work for Kennecott.
 
Previous Home Next

item.title: Ida Weiss 🔊
item.dc:creator: rarodriguez
item.content:encoded:
Ida Fukui Weiss (1925-) was a Japanese-American teenager in Carson City during the war. She later married her husband, Ralph Weiss, who was not Japanese. Ida Weiss was interviewed by Noriko Kunitomi in 1992.
           
[audio mp3="http://digitalhistory.acs.unr.edu/hist300a/sp2017/group1/wp-content/uploads/sites/19/2017/10/WeissI-edited-1.mp3"][/audio]

Transcript

During World War II, it was very hard on the Japanese. My mother would say, “If we hadn’t come to this country, we would not be subjecting our children to all of this.” But I still felt that this country was better.

Being in Japan, you get bombed and all that, and they got burned out and everything like that. This way, we were still sort of restricted. We couldn’t leave and go someplace without approval. You couldn’t move around as freely, but like I say, there were people in Carson that I grew up with that were very kind, and they would sign, saying, “We will vouch for this person. They can go to Reno or wherever.”

***End of Audio***

But I made some very good friends. I don’t think you ever heard of Paul Laxalt; he was the governor of Nevada, and he became a senator. Well, we went to school about the same time, and he still remembered me. I ran into him in Reno, and he remembered me after all those years. And my attorney, Clark Guild, is very prominent in Reno, and we are still good friends. I met my husband at the V.A., because he worked in finance, and I worked in another department. My mother was of the old, old world, not like you young people. She didn’t believe in inter-marriage. And so I took care of my mother; that’s the Japanese custom, too. You don’t stick them in a nursing home. She didn’t speak the language, anyway, so what can you do? So my husband and I, we went together for fourteen years, because my mother didn’t believe in mixed marriages. After my mother died, we waited six months or so, and then we got married, but we’ve been married twenty-two years come June [1992]. That’s a long time, especially the way marriages are these days, and we get along fine. You just mentioned prejudice; did you have difficulty? Not that I can really say, but during the war was very hard, even though my brother was in the United States Army. It was hard, because nobody wanted to give me a job, but there was a man that did give me a job, and I worked for him for about ten years. Then I passed the civil service test, and I went to work for the Veterans Administration Hospital here. Even then, some people did not want to hire me, even though you have the qualifications, you’ve passed the test and all that, but I managed to work myself up to where I was a supervisor when I left. I found out that if you’re Japanese, you have to work a little harder or be a little bit smarter than the next guy.
 
Previous Home Next

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Ida Fukui Weiss (1925-) was a Japanese-American teenager in Carson City during the war. She later married her husband, Ralph Weiss, who was not Japanese...

item.title: Pete Cladianos, Jr.
item.dc:creator: rarodriguez
item.content:encoded:
Pete Cladianos, Jr. (1929-) was a teenager in Reno in the 1940s, and he went to school with Japanese-American students who were interned with their families in California. Cladianos was interviewed by Dwayne Kling in 2000 to 2002.
           

Transcript

When the United States entered World War II, there were a couple of Japanese kids in my school, and they moved them and their families down to Inyokern [California] to the internment camp. It was really foolish, but I guess the government didn’t know what the hell was going to happen. I guess it couldn’t be helped. The father of one of the kids, Mr. Fuji, had a nursery on Wells Avenue, Nevada Nursery. We had a kid named Buster Chikami, and they moved his family, also.

Previous Home Next

item.title: Buddy Fujii 🔊
item.dc:creator: rarodriguez
item.content:encoded:
Buddy Fujii (1932-) was a Japanese-American high-school student in Reno at the time of the war. Buddy Fujii was interviewed by Noriko Kunitomi in 1992.
               
[audio mp3="http://digitalhistory.acs.unr.edu/hist300a/sp2017/group1/wp-content/uploads/sites/19/2017/10/FujiiB-edited.mp3"][/audio]

Transcript

But I never thought of myself as being Japanese when I grew up, because I grew up here [in Reno]. Except for World War II, it never dawned on me that I was different. Even when I looked in the mirror and combed my hair, I never thought I looked any different. I didn’t think about that, because it wasn’t an issue with the kids—the kids that we ran around with and went to school with.

***End of Audio***

And during World War II it wasn’t an issue. It became apparent, but it was not a real stumbling block as far as that’s concerned. It was another obstacle you had to overcome. It was just like going to school and passing courses and doing things that your parents wanted you to do.
 
Previous Home Next

item.title: Judy Matley Edwards 🔊
item.dc:creator: rarodriguez
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_16" align="alignleft" width="288"] Oral History Italian Northern Nevadan Project[/caption]
Judy Matley Edwards (1943-) is a native of Reno and was born into a Swiss-Italian family. Matley Edwards was interviewed by Kara Geiger in 2005.








 

Transcript

My dad, Clifford Matley, was born in 1913. None of the Matley children were named the Italian names. In fact, John Matley, my grandfather, basically told his family that he was German. He married a German woman whose family line was pure German back to day one, and you notice they didn’t get married until after her father had died. She was a very bright woman, my grandmother, Martha Annie Steinberger. She had gone to the university. She had wanted to be a doctor, but her father, in 1900, thought that was not appropriate for a woman to be a doctor.
[audio mp3="http://digitalhistory.acs.unr.edu/hist300a/sp2017/group1/wp-content/uploads/sites/19/2017/10/EdwardsJ-edited.mp3"][/audio]

Transcript

John capitalized upon his German background when he met Martha, and so basically they raised their family as German. Then during—as World War II was approaching and Hitler and his atrocities came to the forefront, John Matley revealed to his family his true background, which was both German as well as Italian.

***End of Audio***

[The Italian version of the family name was Maddalena or de la Maddalena.] During World War I, John and Martha Matley had contributed heavily to the war effort by donating some of their Percheron horses to the government. None of the Matley boys served directly in the wars, either World War I or World War II, but during World War II John also contributed a lot of beef to the war effort and received an Army Navy E Award for meritorious performance. This came from the United States Department of Agriculture. He had furnished more than 300,000 pounds of prime beef for the armed forces during World War II. This would be 300 to 600 animals or more. So, while his ancestors had given hay to support the Austrian army for a period of two or three years, John Matley also made his contribution for freedom in America.
 
Previous Home Next

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Judy Matley Edwards (1943-) is a native of Reno and was born into a Swiss-Italian family. Matley Edwards was interviewed by Kara Geiger in 2005...

item.title: Nello Gonfiantini 🔊
item.dc:creator: rarodriguez
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_19" align="alignleft" width="294"] Oral History Italian Northern Nevadan Project[/caption]
Nello Gonfiantini (1926-), an Italian American, served in the Army Air Corps near the end of World War II. Gonfiantini was interviewed by Mary Larson in 2005.
 
[audio mp3="http://digitalhistory.acs.unr.edu/hist300a/sp2017/group1/wp-content/uploads/sites/19/2017/10/GonfiantiniN2-edited.mp3"][/audio]

Transcript

There was also a Japanese family up there [at Gerlach], a man who had worked on the railroad, and he lost his job, and he had to move from his house to a place further away from the railroad track, and they couldn’t go by the railroad track and that sort of thing. In fact, that family moved to Reno eventually. So it wasn’t just Italians, just anybody who was—it probably was that way against Germans, but there weren’t any Germans that I knew at the time.

***End of Audio***

 
Previous Home Next

item.title: Housing & Employment
item.dc:creator: kweaverghs
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_2051" align="alignleft" width="300"] Bruno's liquor store, UNLV library[/caption] With the construction of Boulder Dam outside of Las Vegas, segregation in employment and housing became a focal point for the civil rights movement in Nevada. During the 1930s, the dam project was the major source of employment for the area. At first blacks were denied employment due to race, and it was only through the intervention of the Las Vegas NAACP branch that they were allowed to work at Boulder Dam. Even then, blacks were systematically excluded from certain types of jobs and housing, and it was during this time that the Westside began to develop as the primary black residential and business community in Las Vegas.
During the 1940s, segregation was the norm for race relations in Las Vegas. With the building of the Basic Magnesium, Incorporated (BMI) plant in 1942-1943, a great number of blacks came to the Las Vegas area to work at the plant. Whole towns from Louisiana and Arizona moved into what is now Henderson to work at the plant, bringing with them their racial attitudes. Segregationist practices at Basic Magnesium included having separate toilet facilities and limiting blacks to menial positions. As part of employment at the plant, the federal government built housing to accommodate the influx of people, but the owners did not provide blacks with housing until after the all-white Victory Village was built. Carver Park was constructed for the black workers, but by the time it was completed, many of the black employees had already settled on the Westside in Las Vegas. Blacks fought to end discrimination at the plant through the unions and other organizations, and this led to a strike of two hundred black workers in 1943. Although not successful, it did show that blacks were going to continue to press for equal opportunities in the employment arena.
Many blacks remained in Las Vegas after World War II ended, and in the 1950s the NAACP’s local branch—led by Dr. Charles West, Dr. James McMillan, Lubertha Johnson, Woodrow Wilson, and Clarence Ray—fought to end segregation in employment and housing throughout the area. Across the state, this fight was carried on in Reno as well, by such people as Eddie Scott, Howard Gloyd, and Clyde Mathews in the 1950s and early 1960s and by Barbara Bennett during the 1960s and 1970s.
It was during the 1950s that the Las Vegas NAACP developed many of the tactics that it used in later desegregating the Strip, using as its primary approach the boycott of businesses that catered to the black community but did not employ blacks. Boycotts were successful in opening up better job opportunities, but even as blacks were now able to find better paying jobs and afford a better lifestyle, many were still not allowed to live anywhere other than the Westside nor enjoy the accommodations of the hotel-casinos being built on the Las Vegas Strip. Discrimination in lending was another issue. Throughout the 1950s, 1960s, and 1970s, the NAACP in Nevada tried to change the loan practices of area banks so that blacks could buy homes outside segregated areas. In Las Vegas, this led Woodrow Wilson to create the Westside Credit Union to provide the necessary loans to buy homes not just in the Westside but also throughout the greater metropolitan area.
In the 1960s, the focus of employment discrimination in Las Vegas shifted to the gaming industry. Casinos were then the major source of employment in the area, yet blacks were limited to menial jobs. With the growth of the tourist industry in Las Vegas, hotel-casinos became more sensitive to boycotts and marches, and the NAACP used the threat of demonstrations during important events to force the gaming industry to end discrimination in employment and open access to public accommodations. The Moulin Rouge Agreement, negotiated in 1960, was a result of this tactic and eventually opened up the Strip to black customers and workers. Employment discrimination in the private sector ended in the mid-1960s, and by the 1970s, housing had also been desegregated. Return Home

item.title: Civil Rights Legislation
item.dc:creator: kweaverghs
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_1253" align="alignleft" width="300"] Slattery Protest[/caption] Legislation in Nevada to end racial discrimination and give blacks civil rights did not begin until the 1950s. The first effort came in 1953, when George Rudiak presented a bill to the assembly to open public accommodations to blacks. The bill failed, and no other legislative attempts occurred until Grant Sawyer’s election as the Governor of Nevada in 1958.
Sawyer’s support gave new momentum to efforts that put Nevada ahead of the nation in terms of civil rights, including Assembly Bill 122, sponsored by Maude Frazier. It was the first legislation that addressed racial discrimination in Nevada, and when it passed in 1959, it ended discrimination in public employment and government contracts.
With support from both the black and white communities, numerous pieces of legislation were passed that ended racial discrimination in private employment and public accommodations. In 1961, the Nevada Equal Rights Commission emerged from this effort, and in 1965, Nevada passed its own version of the 1964 Civil Rights Act, effectively ending discrimination in public life (with the exception of housing).
Woodrow Wilson addressed housing discrimination when he was elected as the first black Nevada Assemblyman in 1967. He proposed legislation in 1968 for an open-housing law in Nevada, which was finally passed in 1971, and by the mid-1970s, legal racial discrimination in all areas of life in Nevada had ended. Return Home

item.title: Moulin Rouge Agreement
item.dc:creator: kweaverghs
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_1251" align="alignleft" width="300"] Moulin Rouge opening night, 1955[/caption] By the end of the 1940s, the gaming industry was the major source of employment in Las Vegas, but segregation limited blacks to the most menial jobs on the Strip and denied them access to the hotel-casinos as customers. The black community in the 1950s sought an end to racial discrimination using boycotts and demonstrations, which culminated in 1960 with the Moulin Rouge Agreement.
The Moulin Rouge Agreement occurred on March 25th, 1960, as part of negotiations between the black community, Las Vegas business leaders, and local and state government officials to avert a demonstration scheduled for the next day on the Las Vegas Strip. The agreement required the gaming industry to stop discriminating against blacks in employment and to open hotel-casinos to blacks as customers. As a result of the settlement, the gaming industry expanded employment opportunities for blacks to include the positions of dealers, floor managers, and personnel managers. Blacks also formed teams to test access to the hotel-casinos. A few casinos, such as the Sal Sagev and Binion's, did not participate in the agreement until later.
Dr. James McMillan was the president of the Las Vegas NAACP at the time and acted as the voice of the black community in the negotiations, while other NAACP members at the meeting included Dave Hoggard, Woodrow Wilson, Bob Bailey, Lubertha Johnson, and Donald Clark. Hank Greenspun of the Las Vegas Sun acted as mediator, and Las Vegas Mayor Oran Gragson and Nevada Governor Grant Sawyer were also instrumental in achieving the agreement. Oscar Crozier, the black owner of the El Morocco, had connections to the gaming industry and played an important role as a liaison between the NAACP and the hotel-casino owners.
Return Home

item.title: Organizations
item.dc:creator: kweaverghs
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_1289" align="alignleft" width="300"] NAACP Meeting, 1950[/caption] The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, or the NAACP, emerged as the leading organization in the struggle for civil rights and the end of segregation in Nevada. The Las Vegas chapter was formed in 1928 through the efforts of Arthur McCants, Clarence Ray, Bill Jones, a Mrs. Nettles, and Zimmy Turner, with McCants serving as the first NAACP president in Nevada.
In the 1930s, the Las Vegas NAACP’s primary goal was getting blacks hired on the Boulder Dam project, while during the 1940s, the group reorganized under new direction and became a prominent voice of the black community. Many of the important individuals in the movement at this time were religious figures, including Bishop Cox, Rev. Cook, and Rev. Simmons. Woodrow Wilson also emerged as an important leader during this period.
Under the guidance of Dr. James McMillan, Dr Charles West, and Lubertha Johnson, the group began to use boycotts and demonstrations in the 1950s to challenge businesses that discriminated against blacks in employment and denied them access to public accommodations. The Reno NAACP branch became active in this decade as well, under the leadership of Eddie Scott, Joe Williams, Howard Gloyd, and Bertha Woodward. It was also during this time that many whites joined the Nevada NAACP. In Las Vegas, white members included George Rudiak, an attorney, and Hank Greenspun, the publisher of the Las Vegas Sun, while Clyde Mathews, a minister, joined the Reno branch. Governor Grant Saywer was also a member.
Individuals from the Las Vegas NAACP started the Nevada Voters League in the 1950s as the black community’s political voice, since the NAACP could not involve itself in partisan politics. The league's primary mission was to influence Nevada—and in particular, Las Vegas—politics and force politicians to address the concerns of black citizens throughout the state.
During the 1960s, Donald Clark and Charles Kellar emerged as the new leadership of the NAACP and directed its efforts in continuing to desegregate employment opportunities as well as the Las Vegas school system. The group also supported the establishment of the Equal Rights Commission to investigate claims of racial discrimination in employment and public accommodations. With the help of these organizations, the last vestiges of legal segregation and racial discrimination ended in the 1970s. Return Home

item.title: Segregated Education
item.dc:creator: kweaverghs
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_1250" align="alignleft" width="300"] Westside School registration [/caption] In the 1930s and 1940s, the schools in Las Vegas were segregated at the elementary and junior high school levels, with the lone high school being integrated. The Westside neighborhood, which developed into the primary black residential and business community in Las Vegas during the 1930s and 1940s, had only one school, and that school was in substandard condition.

As the black population grew, other schools were built in the Westside, but they still lacked the resources of white schools. The Brown v. Board of Education decision in 1954 gave a boost to the efforts of the black community to end segregation in Las Vegas schools. When the decision did not lead to timely integration, the president of the local branch of the NAACP, Charles Kellar, filed suit in federal court in 1968, and that led to negotiations with the school district to desegregate the schools, which occurred only in 1972.

The final plan called for extensive busing of students and the establishment of sixth-grade centers, which were schools in the Westside that white students were bused to during the sixth grade. Black students were bused out of the Westside to predominantly white schools in grades one through five, and the high schools in Las Vegas were integrated. Many in the black community were not satisfied with the plan but considered it the best possible solution at the time. The effort to desegregate the Las Vegas school system was led by Charles Kellar, Woodrow Wilson, Lubertha Johnson, the NAACP, and Mabel Hoggard, who was the first licensed black teacher in Las Vegas and a future superintendent of schools. Return Home

item.title: Mining Economics
item.dc:creator: kweaverghs
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_1274" align="alignleft" width="300"] The Cortez Mine. Barrick Gold Corporation photo.[/caption]Mining in Nevada has changed greatly over the last 150 years, due primarily to advances in technology and in prospecting techniques. During the nineteenth century mining boom on the Comstock, large veins of ore—mainly gold and silver—were being mined. While company mines were perhaps more highly visible, small, individually owned mines were also common in Nevada, and it was not unusual for a family to own a small claim and mine it themselves.
One large change Nevada mining witnessed was the shift in the mid-twentieth century from underground mining, useful for mining large veins, to open pit-mining. Though the amount of a desired mineral was less in the ore mined from open pits, refining processes were developed that could get a profitable amount of minerals out of an ore with a lower yield. The development of larger earthmoving equipment allowed ore to be excavated more quickly, and this, coupled with better refining techniques, allowed mining to remain as a profitable endeavor in Nevada.

For the people who actually labored in Nevada mines, working conditions were often difficult. In the late nineteenth and early to mid-twentieth century, miners worked six or seven days a week, depending on their task within the mine and the mine they worked at, with some miners receiving higher pay based on their skills. There was also less of a division of labor in the early days, with workers having a better grasp of a wide range of tasks and processes. While miners in the early to mid-1900s could perform many of the tasks needed to mine and mill ore, miners by the end of the twentieth century were more specialized, and generally performed only one job throughout their shifts, even if they knew other parts of the process Return Home

item.title: Effect of WWII on Mining
item.dc:creator: kweaverghs
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_1281" align="alignleft" width="300"] Copper Pit at Ruth, Nevada[/caption] World War II had a great influence on mining in Nevada. While restrictions on gold mining had begun almost immediately after Pearl Harbor, the War Production Board issued Limitation Order L-208 in October of 1942, effectively closing the nation’s gold mines all together. The government’s intent in shutting down gold mines was to focus mining on strategic metals and minerals such as lead, zinc, copper and tungsten, which were needed for the war effort. Gold and other precious metals such as silver were deemed “non-strategic.” While many individual miners managed to find employment in strategic-metal mines, the closing of gold and silver operations had a significant impact on the communities that relied on them for jobs as well as support of local businesses. Return Home

item.title: Life in Mining Communities
item.dc:creator: kweaverghs
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_1279" align="alignleft" width="250"] Silver Peak Mining Community[/caption] Many towns in Nevada exist today because of mining. When a large mine was opened, towns were built around them to provide for the men who were working in the mines and their families. It was recognized that in order to keep good miners, companies needed to have comfortable living conditions, so it was not uncommon for companies to not only build bunkhouses and provide room and board, but to build entire towns for their workers.
Many of the mining communities of Nevada were lively and close knit. Town-wide celebrations were very common, especially for the holidays, and barbecues, baseball games, drilling contests, and dances were some of the many activities that kept the residents entertained. Many people recounted their childhoods growing up in mining towns and camps and recalled using the mining facilities, such as old mills and dump yards, as their playgrounds. They also remembered the miners themselves—both rowdy and family oriented, but always hard working—who often stopped at a local bar for an “After-shifter.” Return Home

item.title: Mining Regulations
item.dc:creator: kweaverghs
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_860" align="alignleft" width="300"]Basic Magnesium Inc., 1942. UNLV Special Collections photo.[/caption] While regulations of mines on a state level began in Nevada in 1909, restrictions and legal requirements began to intensify with the rising popularity of the environmental movement in the 1970s and escalated even further during the Clinton administration in the 1990s. Both the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) enacted measures to protect workers and the environment, and many of these were at odds with the mining industry's practices. The lengthy permitting process and on-site inspections attempt to control the effect mining has on the surrounding environment, especially the groundwater, run off, air, and soil. Today, the permitting process to operate a mine may take years to complete. Some feel the regulations are too intrusive, while others feel they are much needed. Return Home

item.title: Women During the War
item.dc:creator: kweaverghs
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_1234" align="alignleft" width="300"] WAC Enlistment Poster[/caption] During World War II, women entered military service in unprecedented numbers, serving as auxiliary forces for the army and navy, thus freeing up men for combat. Women's experiences differed widely depending upon the group with which they were affiliated.
The army and navy each had their own regulations as to women's roles. In the navy, WAVES (Women Accepted for Volunteer Emergency Service) could not serve upon a ship, nor go overseas until the end of the war, so most worked on naval bases in support or clerical roles. In the army and air force (which was still a part of the army during the war), women served in many different positions with the WACs (Women's Army Corps, previously the Women's Auxiliary Army Corps), the WASPs (Women Air Service Pilots), or as nurses.
Beyond regular wartime hardships, those who served with these groups experienced other problems as well. Women in the WASPs flight-tested planes and also ferried them around North America and to Europe, but many of them faced gender discrimination and sexual harassment from male instructors and pilots who thought women were incapable of flying or that it was a man’s job. Black women in various military branches experienced not only gender but racial discrimination, with their training and assignments being strictly limited, in most cases, to menial work like laundry or mess duties. Still, the women carried out their commitments.
Other women during the war worked with the American Red Cross, serving overseas. In this capacity, they were responsible for providing support and recreation to the troops in the rear areas, and they were stationed throughout Europe.
The experiences of women serving in World War II, whether in the army, navy, or the Red Cross, illustrate the contribution these individuals made to the Allies’ victory. The war opened up new opportunities for women that did not exist before the war in military and civilian life.
Return Home

item.title: Italian and German Americans
item.dc:creator: kweaverghs
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_1236" align="alignleft" width="300"]Sierra Ordinance Depot Staff, c. 1943[/caption] During World War II, German Americans and Italian Americans were in a difficult position, as they were associated (either directly or through their heritage) with two of the nations at war with the United States. For the most part, there were few restrictions on German Americans, perhaps because they had been a presence in northern Nevada for so long. Any limitations on the activities of Italian Americans seem to have been sporadic and inconsistent. Some chroniclers recall no regulations, while others remember the internment of non-citizen family members or having firearms or shortwave radios confiscated from their homes. Neither group experienced the widespread uprooting and relocations that Japanese Americans were subjected to.
One aspect specific to the Italian American experience was the community's relationship with former Italian prisoners of war at the Sierra Army Depot in Herlong, California, about sixty miles north of Reno. These Italians were captured in the North African campaign and also after the landings at Anzio in Italy. After Italy signed the armistice on September 8th, 1943, however, many Italian prisoners of war took loyalty oaths supporting the Allies in the war. This was the case with the former POWs at Herlong, who were working for the U.S. Quartermasters Corps. It was common for Italian-American families from the Reno area to make Sunday trips up to the army depot, where they would often bring specialty foods and socialize with the Italian men working there.
Return Home

item.title: Japanese Americans in Nevada
item.dc:creator: kweaverghs
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_1235" align="alignleft" width="300"] Roy Nishiguchi, 1941[/caption] During World War II, the experiences of Japanese-Americans in Nevada were different from their Italian-American or German-American counterparts, and the government singled them out for more severe restrictions. Not all Japanese Americans in Nevada were sent to internment camps, but those that were had to give up their homes, possessions, and businesses because the government feared that they would support Japan during the war.
Those Japanese Americans not sent to internment camps had restrictions placed on their movements and where they could live, and in some cases their bank accounts were frozen. In certain locales they could not live near railroads nor work for them, and many Japanese Americans also faced discrimination from the community at large. These experiences, however, did not deter some Japanese-American men from serving with distinction in the U.S. military during the war.
Return Home

item.title: Mary Date 🔊
item.dc:creator: rarodriguez
item.content:encoded:
Mary Date (1918-) was Japanese American and operated Reno's American Fish Market with her husband both during and after World War II. Mary Date was interviewed by Noriko Kunitomi in 1992.
             
[audio mp3="http://digitalhistory.acs.unr.edu/hist300a/sp2017/group1/wp-content/uploads/sites/19/2017/10/DateM-edited.mp3"][/audio]

Transcript

It was 1941. At that time my husband had a fish market where the [Flamingo] Hilton is now, on Sierra and Commercial [Row]. It was on the south side of the railroad tracks. But we had a bad time, because a lot of people quit patronizing our store because we were Japanese, and the restaurants did the same. But we stayed there for about twenty years. It wasn’t an easy living.

***End of Audio***
 
Previous Home Next
